Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Objectives and Approaches:
The objective of this research is to identify magnetic geometries with ?constant? distribution of magnetic flux, and to demonstrate magnetic components with energy density 30%-50% higher than state of the art. The approach is organized into three tasks: Synthesis of Constant-Flux Magnetic Geometries, Electro-Magnetic Modeling, and Broader Impact. Inductors with multiple windings will be identified based on synthesis factors, and verified by finite-element simulation. Practical processes will be identified for manufacturing of the selected geometries. Design-oriented models will be developed for performance metrics.

Intellectual Merit:
At least 30% of the volume in commercial inductors stores no or negligible energy. The ?constant-flux? concept improves energy density by filling the available volume with as much magnetic (core) materials as practically feasible, then dispersing the windings to shape the distribution of magnetic flux, e.g., to distribute magnetic flux uniformly. Guiding principles will be developed from the structural and field standpoints to realize the constant-flux concept. Performance metrics, such as inductances, capacitances, and quality factor will be modeled, quantified, and compared with the corresponding benchmarks.

Broader Impact:
Demo modules will be developed for rising junior and senior high-school girls who participate in a summer camp called C-Tech2 (Computer and Technology and Virginia Tech) to develop and sustain the students? interest in engineering and sciences. Through an interdisciplinary program called Scieneering, sophomore and junior Scieneers will be selected to execute part of the research plan. Industry mentors will be invited to help establishing a path to commercialization.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intended intellectual outcome of the project is a class of magnetic components with beneficially distributed field, including
- Constant-flux inductor (CFI) with two times the energy density of commercial counterpart; generalized synthesis and design methodologies reported in two journal papers, one disclosure, and two conference papers;
- 2D gap that cuts in half inductor’s loss at light load to save stand-by energy in point-of-load converter; one conference paper documenting the concept;
- Widely separated coils for wireless power transfer with low EMI thanks to co-design of electrical and field metrics;
An added intellectual outcome is an infrastructure for 3D printing of distributed magnetics, including
- A NiCuZn ferrite with loss lower than that of the best commercial ferrite between one and ten megahertz; one journal paper;
- Magnetic pastes with curing temperature comparable to that of conventional assembly process;
- Retrofit 3D printer for dispensing and curing of the aforementioned pastes.
As a part of Broader Impacts, the research results  were disseminated in eight publications at conferences and in journals.  Six industrial partners collaborated to apply the concept to products, and to manufacture the constant-fux inductor.
High-school students were coupled by summer camps, including
- Teaching wireless power transfer technology to C-Tech2 Camp: Thirty students from the C-Tech2 camp (junior and senior girls from high school) learnt about applications of wireless power transfer and experienced experimental hardware in the PI’s laboratory. The exposure helps the students to know more about electrical engineering, power electronics, and energy-related technologies.
- Electrical Engineering Experiments for Imagination Camp: Fifty students from the Imagination Camp (20% female and 20% from underrepresented groups) built a circuit to learn the basics of electrical engineering. The objective was to make the students interested in electronics. At the end, 80% of the students finished the experiment and passed the test in the designated time.

 


Last Modified: 06/02/2016
Modified by: Khai D Ngo

    Constant-Flux Magnetics for Power Conversion
